title: Older generation, what was the equivalent during your time to showing off a sleek smartphone like today? - Quora

response.answer_text: Electronics were hardly “electronic” back in the good ole days. Everything electrical was tube operated. Phones in my town had just converted to dial service from operator service. It was “The Black and White era”. I remember my first day back at the “School House” and I had on my brand new shoes, pants and shirt! I was high-falutin! Once a year I got new school clothes, unless my older brother hit a growth spurt and outgrew his clothes. Some kids showed off their new haircuts. Bill Newman arrived one fall morning I would guess in ‘59 at our brand new school, sporting his Mohawk!!! I was lucky enough to see him that morning. As my memory shows, his hall locker was near mine and there he stood. Putting his coat and lunch in his locker looking PROUD! He was so “outstanding” his do was noticed by the teachers. I can only imagine the rest of what happened. He was escorted to the Principal’s Office. Asked one question: “WHYYYYYYY……??????” The next time I saw him, the next day, he looked “normal”… Original Question: Older generation, what was the equivalent during your time to showing off a sleek smartphone like today?

ty4ta2a Older generation, what was the equivalent during your time to showing off a sleek smartphone like today? Traditionally, for the 16+ crowd, this would be filled by the automobile that the person owns, unfortunately. It was this very attachment of a costly environmentally destructive item that really extracts loads of ongoing money from their owner that -ahem- ‘paved the way’ for the scum who make combustion engine automobiles and run oil companies to become the cancerous stain on civilization that they are. In fact, as I recall from propaganda footage, cars were billed in the 1950’s as synonymous with “freedom”. Do note that this was done in a nation which fancies themselves by their long passed national character of “the land of the free”. Genius bit of advertising that will land some folk in a very deep dark pit in Hell. So yeah, “cars” were the cell phone of the boomers, and I suppose game consoles were the cell phones of Gen X-ers and Gen Y-ers perhaps it was personal computers, which leads us to Millennial's for whom the cell phone was the cell phone.
